results.title: The Swarm
results.creator_credit: Irwin Allen and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: From celebrated epic disaster movie director Irwin Allen, this tale of destruction wrought by swarms of millions of killer African and South American bees stands alongside “The Poseidon adventure” and “Towering Inferno” in Allen’s production record, though with a somewhat lesser impact. Entomologist Brad Crane (Michael Caine) discovers that deadly South American bees have been breeding with their harmless relations in the North. Worse still, something is making them come together in huge killer swarms and the terror of their destruction threatens to spread throughout North America. As the bees close in on Houston, Crane joins forces with General Slater (Richard Widmark) to try and stop the devastation. Filmed with an estimated 22 million bees, this doomsday epic also boasts a collection of stars including Katherine Ross, Olivia de Havilland, Henry Fonda, Fred MacMurray, Richard Chamberlain, Jose Ferrer, Patty Duke Astin, Lee Grant and Bradford Dillman.

results.title: The English patient [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Anthony Minghella, Saul Zaentz and Miramax Films
results.brief_description: Based on Michael Ondaatje’s Booker prize-winning novel, “The English Patient” is a sumptuous romance set during the second world war in the deserts of North Africa and the rolling hills of Tuscany. Hana (Juliette Binoche), a shell-shocked Canadian nurse decides to stay in an abandoned villa to nurse a mysterious English patient (Ralph Fiennes) who is burned beyond recognition and doesn’t remember his name. Gradually we learn the truth of his identity and of his doomed love affair with Katherine Mansfield (Kristen Scott Thomas). (Awards: Winner of 9 Oscars at the 1996 Academy Awards, including Best Film, Best Director, Best Supporting Actress - Juliette Binoche and Best Cinematography for Australian John Seale)

results.title: Life is beautiful
results.creator_credit: Roberto Benigni, Gianluigi Braschi, Elda Ferri and Melampo Cinematografica
results.brief_description: In this World War II tragicomedy, writer/director Roberto Benigni portrays Guido, who moves during the 30s from the country to a Tuscan town, where he falls in love with schoolteacher Dora. Dora likes Guido, but she remains faithful to her pompous fiancee, causing Guido to come up with inventive ways of wooing her. Meanwhile, anti-semitic attitudes lead to attacks against Jewish members of the community, including Guido’s uncle. Leaping ahead five years, during World War II, Guido and Dora are married with a son Giosue. After they are imprisoned in a concentration camp, Guido goes to elaborate lengths to keep his son from understanding the truth of their situation. In Italian with English subtitles. Cast includes: Roberto Benigni, Nicoletta Braschi, Giustino Durano and Giorgio Cantarini.

results.title: What women want [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Nancy Meyers, Matt Williams, Gina Matthews, Bruce Davey, Susan Cartonis, Centropolis Effects, Wind Dancer Productions, Paramount Pictures and ICON
results.brief_description: Nick Marshall (Mel Gibson) is a real ladies man. Raised by his mother, a Las Vegas showgirl, he has a somewhat distorted perception of what women really want, and an enormous ego. When he is passed over for an executive position in the advertising agency for a woman his chauvinistic attitude worsens. A freak accident while trying to brainstorm ideas for a new advertising campaign, leaves Nick with the ability to hear what women think. Amazed by his new talent Nick seeks the help of a therapist (Bette Midler) who suggests he think of it as a gift and not a curse, and to use this to his advantage. Nick sets his sights on Darcy McGuire (Helen Hunt), the new creative director in the agency. At first his plan works, and he undermines Darcy at every opportunity, until he realises Darcy has feelings for him, and that he feels the same way about her. Cast also includes Marisa Tomei, Mark Feurstein, Lauren Holly, Valerie Perrine, Delta Bourke and Alan Alda.

results.title: Newsfront [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Phil Noyce, Richard Brennan, David Elfick and Palm Beach Pictures
results.brief_description: This is the dramatic story of the newsreel cameramen who lived and worked in Australia during the golden era of the newsreel from 1948 to 1956. Len Maguire is a top cameraman whose devotion to his work and loyalty to his company creates conflict with both his colleagues and the people he loves. Amy is a production assistant working in a predominantly male environment and Len’s brother, Frank, heads the Australian branch of an American newsreel company in competition with Len’s company.

results.title: The Jigsaw Man
results.creator_credit: Terence Young, Benjamin Fisz and J&M Entertainment
results.brief_description: Spy thriller inspired by the true story of British intelligence officer and Soviet spy Kim Philby (1912-1988). Having defected to Russia in 1979, Sir Philip Kimberly (Michael Caine), Cambridge graduate and former Director-General of M.I.6 is called upon by the Russians to carry out one last mission. With a different identity and a face altered beyond recognition by plastic surgery, he is sent back to England in the guise of a Soviet citizen to retrieve a secret dossier of names he supposedly hid there several years ago. When he decides to defect a second time the viewer is drawn into a complex web of espionage, counter-espionage and counter-counter-espionage where nothing is as it at first appears. Cast includes Laurence Olivier, Susan George and Robert Powell.

results.creator_credit: Mark Rydell, Don Devlin, Harry Gittes, Tony Bill, Columbia and Safecracker Productions

results.title: Funeral in Berlin
results.creator_credit: Ken Adam, Guy Hamilton, Charles Kasher and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: In this 60’s espionage classic (a follow up to “The Ipcress File”), Michael Caine reprises his role as British secret agent, Harry Palmer, who reluctantly takes on a job in Berlin where his task is to organise the defection of a wily Russian military commander from East Berlin. Using his local underworld contacts, he arranges for the border crossing to take place in a coffin, as part of a mock funeral. Pursued by a glamorous Israeli agent and hindered by double dealing within his own organisation, Harry Palmer brings his own Cockney cunning to the fore to survive when his plans are thwarted and the wrong body arrives in the coffin. Based on a novel by Len Deighton.

results.title: Too late the hero [Widescreen]
results.brief_description: Robert Aldrich’s “Too late the hero” is a fine wartime drama set in WW II starring Cliff Robertson as Lt. Lawson, a US Navy interpreter who is ordered - against his own wishes - to join a British Commando unit in the South Pacific tasked with destroying a Japanese communications centre. Led by the incompetent Captain Hornsby (Denholm Elliott), the unit includes burnt-out soldiers - personified by the embittered, cynical Tosh Hearne (Michael Caine) - who want no part of the false glory inherent in this suicide mission for which they have been ‘volunteered’. The mission goes badly, with almost all of the men dying and the Japanese commander, Major Yamaguchi (Ken Takakura), taunting the survivors to give themselves up, working a psychological battle of wills against the allies as they turn on each other. Made in 1970 at a time when America was embroiled in Vietnam, “Too late the hero” is an intelligent, provocative and dramatic exploration of the nature of war and the role of the hero. Its portrayal of bloody and random killing and the manner in which men are reduced to their primal survival instincts during war is a milestone in the development of the war film. In addition, its avoidance of a standard caricatured portrayal of the Japanese is noteworthy. Filmed on location in the Philippines, “Too late the hero” is visually stunning, and boasts one of Michael Caine’s finest performances. Cast also includes Henry Fonda.

results.title: Blood and wine
results.creator_credit: Bob Rafelson, Jeremy Thomas and Blood and wine Productions
results.brief_description: Alex Gates (Jack Nicholson) is down on his luck: struggling to keep afloat his wine business, unhappily married to the snappy Suzanne (Judy Davis), who gave him the money to first start the business, and step-father to the hostile Jason (Stephen Dorff), Gates seeks an escape. His secret lover, the Latino Gabriella (Jennifer Lopez), is a nanny at a rich Florida family home, which provides the necessary inside connection for Gates and his ruthless partner-in-crime, Victor Spansky, played to hammy effect by Michael Caine, to steal a set of expensive diamonds. Though the robbery goes according to plan, all hopes are quickly dashed when Gates gets into a domestic brawl just before leaving to cash in the jewels and his wife and step-son take off with the goods. What follows is a series of tragic events and complications as Spansky and Gates attempt to retrieve the jewels, and Gabriella becomes involved with Jason. Ultimately, the deceitful are punished and the good set free. “Blood and Wine” has all the elements of film noir - lust, deceit, revenge, greed, crime, and, most importantly, the desire to escape conventional constraints. Bob Rafelson, who has carved out a reputation as a director of contemporary film noir, remaking such classics as “The Postman Always Rings Twice” (1981), and character-studies of drifting and alienation in middle-class America, continues in “Blood and Wine” his close collaboration with Jack Nicholson, making this their eighth film and the final instalment in a trilogy of films of ‘dysfunctional families’, including “Five Easy Pieces” (1970) and “The King of Marvin Gardens” (1972). Interweaving familial ties with criminal pursuit, “Blood and Wine” makes Oedipal themes - such as the struggle between father and son - typical of film noir more overt. Ultimately, stereotyped characters (sexy Latino, frustrated housewife, ruthless, exotic criminal) and an inability to reach the dramatic heights or transgressive thrills of classic noir makes “Blood and Wine” a rather conventional reworking of the genre.

Ultimately, the deceitful are punished and the good set free. “Blood and Wine” has all the elements of film noir - lust, deceit, revenge, greed, crime, and, most importantly, the desire to escape conventional constraints. Bob Rafelson, who has carved out a reputation as a director of contemporary film noir, remaking such classics as “The Postman Always Rings Twice” (1981), and character-studies of drifting and alienation in middle-class America, continues in “Blood and Wine” his close collaboration with Jack Nicholson, making this their eighth film and the final instalment in a trilogy of films of ‘dysfunctional families’, including “Five Easy Pieces” (1970) and “The King of Marvin Gardens” (1972). Interweaving familial ties with criminal pursuit, “Blood and Wine” makes Oedipal themes - such as the struggle between father and son - typical of film noir more overt. Ultimately, stereotyped characters (sexy Latino, frustrated housewife, ruthless, exotic criminal) and an inability to reach the dramatic heights or transgressive thrills of classic noir makes “Blood and Wine” a rather conventional reworking of the genre.
